column5: Need Code for Direct Secure Messaging
column35:
2021-02-23 03:24;hbuitendijk;[~LisaRNelson] This may be duplicate of UP-124 (https://jira.hl7.org/browse/UP-124) that has been in the queue since October.  That terminology is owned by InM and I'm hoping that we can get approval this Thursday so it can move forward.

UP-124 aims to change Table 0202 rather than Table 0201.  Table 0201 can remain the same if we update Table 0202.
column36:
2021-03-10 12:58;hbuitendijk;This topic was discussed in InM on February 25 ([https://confluence.hl7.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=97482379)]. 

Considering the dependency of XDM on XTN.3 to be "internet" that would be in play in the same use case, there was agreement that UP-162, adding DSM (Direct Secure Messaging) to table 0201 used in XTN.2 would be more appropriate.

Motion: Approve the content of UP-162 to add 'DSM' to table 0201; clarify when to use internet/net in XTN.3

based on IHE usage of internet and close UP-124 since it addresses .

the same need. [Hans Buitendijk|https://confluence.hl7.org/display/~hbuitendijk]/  [Nick Radov|https://confluence.hl7.org/display/~nradov].  13/2/0

 

Depending on whether it is easier to progress UP-124 through the process (it is further along) than UP-162 we will proceed.
Reply
column37: 2021-03-12 10:54;hbuitendijk;[~LisaRNelson]: We got everything working on UP-124, so this one can be closed out and just point to UP-124.  Thank you!

column42: 2021-01-11 10:16;AMS;Where is this code system expected to be used? The concepts yes, no, and various flavors of null are used in existing value sets. Has consideration been given to making these code less particular to Dx POA?
column43: 2021-01-11 01:09;marc.duteau;To answer your first question, this is an external code system used in the US for billing as CMS requires one of these codes for "all diagnoses reported on claims involving inpatient admissions to general acute care hospitals." I don't know the process CMS used for creating their code system so I don't have an answer your second question, but since it's an external code system I think that whether we agree or disagree with the way they constructed their code system it's still important for it to be represented in hl7.terminology.org as an external code system.

column47:
2021-01-22 11:19;feisenberg;The Clinical Quality Information WG reviewed this value set on 1/22/2021. We agree with creating this code system and we would like to see the codes this code system represents harmonize with existing value sets referenced by various Resources, Profiles and Implementation Guides. We find the code system and the codes valuable for expressing quality measures and clinical decision support artifacts. We also look forward to publication and publication to the continuous integration build with subsequent publication events at Terminology.HL7.org (THO) such that VSAC will be able to import it.  The WG agrees by consensus with these statements.  
Floyd Eisenberg, co-chair

column36: 2020-12-02 10:23;lloyd;Canonical URLs should never end in .html.  Also, should never change canonical URLs once officially published.  We can update the existing metadata to point to a new page, but it's never appropriate to change a canonical URL if there's any chance it's been used in production systems.
column37: 2020-12-02 11:26;Rob_McClure;The comment Loyd has made is the current expected approach - no change if published. Perhaps there are very compelling reasons that can be brought forth and documentation that this uri is not implemented. Metadata can change.

column39: 2020-12-02 11:09;lloyd;Canonical URLs should never have .html in them.  They need to be independent of syntax (because they're going to be used to retrieve HTML, JSON, XML, RDF and maybe other things.  Also, can we be confident that no one's implemented the old URL?  (Less concern here given that it's relatively new, but should still perform due diligence to be safe.)

column36: 2020-12-02 11:15;lloyd;Can't have a canonical that ends in .html.  Also can't have a canonical that's the same as proposed for a different code system - all canonicals must be unique.  Finally, are we confident that no-one's implemented the previously published URL?  We can't change a URL unless we're confident that no-one's used it in real systems or those who have used it are comfortable with the change.

column5: NEW Sensitivity Code
column35:
2020-12-04 05:56;k.connor;CHANGE OBJECT= [https://terminology.hl7.org/ValueSet-v3-ActInformationSensitivityPolicy.html]

ActCode_ActPolicyType_ActPrivacyPolicy_InformationSensitivityPolicy

 

Description: Policy for handling information related to an identifier of an information subject, which will be afforded heightened confidentiality.
 Usage Note: Such policies may govern the sensitivity of information related to an identifier of an act, such as the identifier of a contract; a role, such as a citizen, a patient, a practitioner, or an organization; or an entity such as a medical device due to potential impact on the privacy, well-being, safety or integrity of an information subject. For example, protection against identity fraud or counterfeit.

Rationale

The initial use case for an identifier information sensitivity code arose in DaVinci discussions, which was raised by AMA HL7 members, led by Celine Lefebvre <Celine.Lefebvre@ama-assn.org>, FM cochair, is to address the vulnerability of practitioner identifiers to identity fraud.  While in the US it's true that some practitioner identifiers, such as NPI, are accessible if one queries the NPPES on particular provider individuals/organizations, that search would not yield association with specific patients/clinical records/claims, so the risk of identity theft is less than not adding "need to know" protections of NPI identifiers in content exchange. 

On subsequent consideration, proposers determined that there are numerous use cases for protecting identifiers, including patient citizen IDs, such as SSN, driver's license, student IDs, and health plan IDs.  In addition, there are use cases for protecting sensitive organizational identifiers, e.g., sensitive service clinics, as well as medical device IDs, e.g., those used by a VIP. 

For these reasons, we recognize the need to add an identifier information sensitivity code as a child to the ActCode_ActPolicyType_ActPrivacyPolicy_InformationSensitivityPolicy
column36: 2020-11-02 11:16;tedhl7geek;Apologies, but the infrastructure was updated a few days ago for correct coremif generation and your proposal cannot be built until you update the templates and other parts of the content in your branch with the current master in BitBucket.  Note that these changes are NOT in the content you are proposing but are part of the infrastructure; the old data from the master when you created your proposal can no longer be successfully built with the IGPubisher  Please pull and merge and resubmit.

Just one quick note. The 'Change Objects' field is supposed to be used for the current state of the artifact that you are modifying as part of the proposal. In this case, it should be [https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/CodeSystem-v3-ActCode.html.] With that said, it is really helpful to have the Bitbucket commit link like the one you added. We are discussing how to incorporate those into the proposals as well. 

It will likely be helpful for reviewers to update the 'Change Objects' field as I indicated above for your three tickets, but feel free to leave the other link below it. Reviewers are expecting that to be the current state, so they may be confused by the commit diff.
column39:
2020-12-03 10:46;john_moehrke;What happened to the  _EntitySensitivityPolicyType, should these not be included in the valueset "InformationSensitivtyPolicy????  AND the reason I ask is because this new code seems more line an  _EntitySensitivityPolicyType, than an _ActInformationSensitiviityPolicy.

 

Could we make the code more readable? An acronym, that is not even spelled out as the display name, seems unfriendly.
column40:
2020-12-03 06:27;k.connor;Hi John,

Interesting questions as usual.
h1. RE Could we make the code more readable? An acronym, that is not even spelled out as the display name, seems unfriendly.

As I understand it, the code should be unique and doesn’t need to reflect the concept in any way – could be “TUNASAND” with display name “identifier information sensitivity”.

I.e., Parsimony and uniqueness are the desired result.

 *RE What happened to the  _EntitySensitivityPolicyType, should these not be included in the valueset "InformationSensitivtyPolicy????  AND the reason I ask is because this new code seems more line an  _EntitySensitivityPolicyType, than an _ActInformationSensitiviityPolicy.*

 As far as I know, those are abstract differentiations in the code system.  They are not carried forward in value sets. 

 That said, “identifier Sensitivity” would be in  [https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/branches/UP-129-new-sensitivity-code/ValueSet-v3-ActInformationSensitivityPolicy.html] under “ActInformationSensitivityPolicy” because it’s not just sensitivity of an Entity.  E.g., a Medical Record Identifier as well as a patient/provider identifier could be a sensitive identifier.  So I think this code is in the correct place.  The ActInformationSensitivtyPolicy was meant to include sensitive information codes that include the sensitivity across the information as well as the entity.  I realize that’s clear as mud, but the differentiation is based on RIM classes, which don’t translate readily to FHIR.  See the description e.g.: "Usage Note: Such policies may govern the sensitivity of information related to an identifier of an act, such as the identifier of a contract.."  A medical record id would be similarly sensitive as would be the patient/role and individual/entity.

 The v3 definition of the abstract header _ActInformationSensitivityPolicy [abstract term] = Types of sensitivity policies that apply to Acts. Act.confidentialityCode is defined in the RIM as "constraints around appropriate disclosure of information about this Act, regardless of mood."

 The v3 definition of the abstract header _EntityInformationSensitivityPolicy [abstract term] = Types of sensitivity policies that may apply to a sensitive attribute on an Entity.

 The v3 definition of the abstract header _RoleInformationSensitivityPolicy [abstract term] = Types of sensitivity policies that apply to Roles.

 The idea was to differentiate sensitive information codes that are across all (ActInformationSensitivityPolicy) vs ones specific to only Entity or Role classes in V3.

 [https://bitbucket.hl7.org/projects/UTG/repos/utg/pull-requests/1/diff]

  <concept>

    <code value="IDS"/>

    <display value="Identifier Sensitivity"/>

    <definition value="Policy for handling information related to an identifier of an information subject, which will be afforded heightened confidentiality. Usage Note: Such policies may govern the sensitivity of information related to an identifier of an act, such as the identifier of a contract; a role, such as a citizen, a patient, a practitioner, or an organization; or an entity such as a medical device due to potential impact on the privacy, well-being, safety or integrity of an information subject. For example, protection against identity fraud or counterfeit."/>

    <property>

      <code value="status"/>

      <valueCode value="active"/>

    </property>

    <property>

      <code value="internalId"/>

      <valueCode value="24800"/>

    </property>

    <property>

      <code value="subsumedBy"/>

      <valueCode value="_ActInformationSensitivityPolicy"/>

    </property>

  </concept>

column5: NEw SecurityLabelMark Code
column35: 2020-11-02 11:15;tedhl7geek;Apologies, but the infrastructure was updated a few days ago for correct coremif generation and your proposal cannot be built until you update the templates and other parts of the content in your branch with the current master in BitBucket.  Note that these changes are NOT in the content you are proposing but are part of the infrastructure; the old data from the master when you created you proposal can no longer be successfully built with the IGPubisher  Please pull and merge and resubmit.
column36:
2020-12-03 10:36;john_moehrke;I think there needs to be care to explain how this "security policy" code relates to the status code that the object it is marking also indicates. That is to say, where the object being marked has already workflow based status, how is this security-policy code to be used? Having more than one way to indicate that an object is draft seems problematic. I am not against having more than one way, just that we must be clear about the potential conflicts. We should at minimum warn the implementer of these potential conflicts.  

For example when this "security policy" code is used on a FHIR Observation. What is the ramifications of the Observation saying .status="final", where the security tag indicated it is draft? What is the ramification of the Observation.status indicating draft, while the security tag does NOT?  This FHIR example is just one way this will happen in FHIR, and FHIR is not the only place where there are workflow indicators in objects.

I think this is a problematic security tag... and I am not convinced it is a "security-policy" code. If it must be a security tag, then it should be an "Integrity" code, not a "security-policy" code.  It seems like the need for the code is unclear, and that the recommended new code might not fit the need that is not stated.
column37:
2020-12-03 06:22;k.connor;Hi John,

This is not a "Security Policy" in the sense of a policy used to make a decision by an ACS.  It's a security policy requirement to render a Privacy Mark code to end users.

It just happens that I put Privacy Mark codes under SecurityPolicy in the v3 hierarchy along with CUIMarks.

It is a sibling of the COPY mark you asked to be added.

It’s simply a trigger to render DRAFT for end user display.

By definition, Privacy Marks are not used in access control decisions so if someone set the observation status to final AND included DRAFTMark or COPYMark code – the access control system would operate on the observation final status despite displaying "DRAFT".  We can't stop Security Labelers from doing something incoherent.

See the description of the parent PrivacyMark [abstract term]

An abstract code for human readable marks indicating, e.g., the level of confidentiality protection, an authorized compartment, the integrity, or the handling instruction required by applicable policy. Such markings must be displayed as directed by applicable policy on electronically rendered information content and any electronic transmittal envelope or container; or on hardcopy information and any physical transmittal envelope or container.

Examples of protocols for marking displays on electronic or hardcopy rendered content: Across the top or "banner" of each page ; as a watermark placed diagonally cross each page; at the bottom or "footer" of each page; and may be displayed at the beginning of any portion within the content that required markings different than other portions of the content. The banner or top of page marking typically acts as a "high watermark" by including all of the markings made on any marked portions within the entirety of the information content.

[https://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem-v3-ActCode.html]

Description: A displayed mark indicating that the electronic or hardcopy information is still under development and is not yet considered to be ready for normal use.
column39:

column40:
2020-12-10 08:56;k.connor;RE Carmela's question in JIRA “Is John's issue resolved? If so, John, would you please change your vote from negative to affirmative?” 

I already tried to addressed John’s concerns  @ https://jira.hl7.org/browse/UP-128, and he hasn’t responded.  His concerns are orthogonal to the proposed COPYMark code.

 He’d previously asked me to create a DRAFTMark code, which is very similar.

 That code, as well as the proposed DRAFTMark code, are not to be construed as access control codes, and should not be used by an Access Control System to make decisions.

 Privacy Mark Descriptions/Definitions from the literature
| |Human readable security labels, which are rendered in the graphic user interface on accessed electronic information, are called “privacy marks.” The act of enabling the rendering of a privacy mark is called “privacy marking”.|
|If present, the privacy-mark is not used for access control. The content of the privacy-mark may be defined by the security policy in force (identified by the security-policy-identifier) which may define a list of values to be used. Alternately, the value may be determined by the originator of the security-label. [[ISO 22600-3|#ISO226003] Section A.3.4.3]|

 COPYMark security label tags are other Privacy Mark codes are intended to instruct an end user system what to display to end users.

 Like DRAFTMark, an implementer could mistakenly instruct an end user system to render a display that is out of synch with the actual status of the displayed information.

 For example, if I misassign a COPYmark tag in meta.security to displayed information, which has the status of created but not attested to, and which has “created” as a Provenance status, the end user could think that the status is a replication rather than an original. It may be the case that there should not be a copy available if the author hasn’t attested to it yet.

 This misalignment should not affect access control as privacy marks are not intended to be used for that purpose per definition.

I can’t resolve the issues that John raised about misapplying Privacy Marks other than to state that the Privacy Marks should align with the access control status.

We can’t prevent implementers from assigning security labels that are not in alignment with reasonable access control policies.

 John will need to address how my response doesn’t satisfy his concerns.
column41:
2020-12-11 05:20;john_moehrke;I don't see anything that I can do but comment. 

 

I was not objecting due to a potential to use it wrong. I was pointing out that a "DRAFTMark" seems to be more closely an integrity tag, than a policy tag. It just seems in the wrong group.
column42:
2020-12-12 01:18;k.connor;John,

The current integrity label codes [http://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/fhir-security-label-ds4p/branches/master/ValueSet-valueset-integrity.html]  don't include a code for DRAFT that might be used by an access control system to limit access because the labeled content is not complete.  But if it did, it would to some extent dup a status code on incomplete.  Perhaps we should add one if the access control policies require this for a use case where the content status is not sufficient.

That said, the purpose of DRAFTMark is to trigger the UI to displace this status to an end user.  As with all Privacy Marks, it is not used to control access.  Entirely different purposes, which you seem to be conflating.

2021-01-12 12:39;k.connor;RE [~AMS] added a comment - Yesterday

A PrivacyMark code is an instruction of what to display to an end user.  DRAFTMark, once rendered, is intended to inform the end user that the Privacy Marked content has the status of "draft", but that different from having a status code of draft, which may change workflow or be used for access control.

That is to say the code and display do not indicate this is specific only to a "minor"; yet the definition is specific to a "minor".  Should the definition be more on an individual, or should the code change to be specific to a minor?   It appears that the intention of the word "Assent" vs "Consent" is implying minor vs adult. Is this globally understood? Is this well understood? I think the concept of a minor vs adult is understood. Can we include that in the code and display?

<code value="USResearchInformedAssent"/>
 <display value="Informed Assent for Research"/>
 <definition value="An informed assertion by a minor who is a candidate research subject, of the individual's willingness to participate in research. Assent means a child's affirmative agreement to participate in a clinical investigation. Mere failure to object should not, absent affirmative agreement, be construed as assent. The minor's assent must be accompanied by parental or guardian consent that the minor participate in a specified research. The assent is not legally binding, however, the accompanying consent is legally binding. Background: In the US, informed assent is governed under 21 CFR Part 50, Subpart D - Additional Safeguards for Children in Clinical Investigations. Available at https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/21/part-50/subpart-D" />
column38:
2020-12-04 06:22;k.connor;CHANGE OBJECT = [https://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem-v3-ActCode.html]

ActCode_ActPolicyType_ActConsent_ActPrivacyConsentDirective_ActUSPrivacyConsentDirective

RE John's comment - the difference between assent and consent in research is internationally well understood.  Might check the citation for further information.

Since the link to the published examples don't resolve correctly, here are the descriptions for these codes found if you drill down from the THO front page

USResearchInformedAssent (Informed Assent for Research)

Description:

An informed assertion by a minor who is a candidate research subject, of the individual's willingness to participate in research. Assent means a child's affirmative agreement to participate in a clinical investigation. Mere failure to object should not, absent affirmative agreement, be construed as assent. The minor's assent must be accompanied by parental or guardian consent that the minor participate in a specified research. The assent is not legally binding, however, the accompanying consent is legally binding. Background: In the US, informed assent is governed under 21 CFR Part 50, Subpart D - Additional Safeguards for Children in Clinical Investigations. Available at [https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/21/part-50/subpart-D]

USResearchInformedConsent (Informed Consent for Research)

Description:

An informed assertion by an adult, or the parent/guardian of a minor who is a candidate research subject, of the individual's willingness to participate in a specified research study. The consent is legally binding. Background: In the US, informed assent is governed under 49 CFR § 11.116 - General Requirements for Informed Consent. Available at [https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/49/11.116]

USBroadResearchConsent(Broad Consent for Research)

Description:

An informed assertion by an adult, or the parent/guardian of a minor who is a candidate research subject, of the individual's willingness to participate in a specified research study. The consent is legally binding. Background: In the US, informed assent is governed under 49 CFR § 11.116 - General Requirements for Informed Consent. Available at https://www.law.cornell.edu/cfr/text/49/11.116

Description = An individual authorized to reclassify labeled content and to provide rationale for doing so as directed by a classification guide. The intent is to augment the list of classifier roles, including classifier, derivative classifier, upgrader, downgrader, with the role of a classifier authorized to change security label per policy.

column54:
2021-01-11 04:29;k.connor;Hi

 

Reclassifier, along with Classifier, Upgrader, Downgrader, Derivative Classifier, are all _AgentRoleTypes, which are privileges granted certain the actors to do certain acts.  Much like the other AgentRoleType codes, such as AMENDER, REVIEWER, VALIDATOR, these roles may never be exercised, or if exercised, might not result in executing the ACT to which the roles are associated.  A VALIDATOR might decide not to validate.  Likewise, a Reclassifier may be tasked with regularly reviewing classifications - e.g., security labels, can deciding whether the labels are still correct or need to be changed because the labeled content has changed.  I.e., these are roles and not participation by the criteria discussed above.

ABSTRACT CONCEPT: _AgentRoleType [abstract term]
h3. Description:

Parties that may or should contribute or have contributed to an Act.

Happy to host a call to discuss with interested parties.  I'd like to have the discussion during a Security WG call.  We have a call tomorrow  - See [https://confluence.hl7.org/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=97474805]

{color:#000000}Weekly calls Tuesdays 3PM ET {color}

[https://us02web.zoom.us/j/89559883576?pwd=ckd0N2V1L1FybXhhbHhVdElQekg2QT09]

Or schedule a call on Thurs/Friday 1/21 and 1/21 at an agreed to time as we'll be doing Security WGM sessions that week.
column55:
2021-01-11 05:26;lloyd;We don't use Role to represent permissions/privileges - that's handled via Act.  (There's a specific mood of PERM' for that.)  Roles indicate a passive capacity that the player has - independent of any particular type of activity.  If you're a nurse or receptionist or mother or attorney, that's totally silent about what you're *doing* in the role.  Being a reviewer, amender, or something else is always a participation.

I'd suggest putting out a Doodle poll to find an agreeable time.  I can't do Tue. at 3 Eastern.
column56: 2021-01-11 07:57;k.connor;On Lloyd's criteria, there are alot of RoleType codes that need reviewing so suggest that this is a larger topic that Vocabulary needs to take up.  FHIR value sets for Roles have mushed together both roles and participation types so if we're going to address, need to do a clean sweep of all.  The role codes submitted under AgentRoleType follow that parent definition.  Maybe we need to move past the RIM model going forward?
column57:
2021-01-22 02:09;k.connor;The three negative voters were among those that approved the AgentRoleType harmonization proposal 201603 Add new specializations of _AgentRoleType in c:RoleCode under _AffiliationRoleType, which cited the difference between a functional role for which an entity is provisioned by an access control system from recording of an entity's participation in an act for which the entity may or may not have been provisioned.  Functional roles, which is a security concept, is not equivalent to a participation role or participation function in an act.

[http://www.hl7.org/documentcenter/public/harmonization/March2016FinalResults.zip]

In 201911 harmonization, the addition of UPGRADER as an additional leaf to RoleCode_AffiliationRoleType_AgentRoleType, was unanimously approved.  Voters included Ted and Lloyd.  Now AMS, Lloyd and Ted are objecting to adding one leaf code RECLASSIFER to the same set of codes.  In light of this history, I hope they'll review their previous votes and the rationale given for the need for these codes and consider changing their votes, if they can figure out how to do that.

the decision was made to reject UP-121 Adding Reclassifier proposal, and to instead  create a new Security Functional Role Code System independent of RIM structures for purposes of security provisioning of clearances and access control.  A new UP to do so will be created and linked here in a follow up comment.

column39:
2022-03-03 08:58;LisaRNelson;We need the metadata that exists.  How are these referenced in CDA R2.0?  They are concept  domains, so the won't have an OID assigned in CDA.  Rob says he would need to look these up in Rosetree to check if they have OIDs there.  He could use those OIDS, but it may not be important to use those OIDS. It may be ok to just create OIDs for these.  For DocumentType, you may not find this.  At the CDA R2.0 level, it is a concept domain, so you would need to create a value set for this.  You should have the C-CDA LOINC Document Ontology as the minimum and an example binding.  

How will we approach this? Rob will look in Rosetree to see if there are OIDs to use those when creating these in THO.  Bind as an example value set when used since these were Concept Domain. If Rob can't find an OID, then he will make one up.
The RIM should have references for these Concept Domains - we would want to use RIM 2.07 because that is what CDA R2.0 was frozen to.  Back then, they still hadn't sorted out the distinction between Concept Domain, Code System, and Value Set.  
You may run into x_whatever things.... 
It may be difficult to determine what concepts actually belong in the value sets.
We may need to create a Code System
DocumentType is an abstract code under actCode.

Austin found some clues Normative Web addition of CDA .
Austin will help dig up more clues on this.
column40:
2022-03-03 11:41;Austin_Kreisler;In general, the CDA R2 specification was built on RIM 2.07, where the distinction between codesystem, valueset and concept domain had not been clarified, they were all called vocabulary domains. To be able to start publishing CDA IG’s built on CDA R2 using FHIR Publishing, these will all need to be represented as value sets even though most are effectively concept domains as they became to be known in subsequent versions of the RIM. The first item, ActClassOrganizer clearly can be represented as valueset with a set of codes.
h2. http://terminology.hl7.org/ValueSet/v3-ActClassOrganizer

A valueset for ActClassOrganizer should have the following values, all drawn from ActClass, and all children of ActClassOrganizer in RIM 2.07:

ORGANIZER, CATEGORY, DOCBODY, DOCSECT, TOPIC, FOLDER

Austin’s Notes: As far as I can tell, the base CDA R2 standard does *not* use this concept domain. CDA uses the following: x_ActClassDocumentEntryOrganizer. ActClassOrganizer does appear in the voc.xsd which is one of the core xml schemas that CDA (and any V3 specification) uses. I suspect that is how it has been pulled into CDA R2, even though it’s not actually used in the specification.
h2. http://terminology.hl7.org/ValueSet/v3-DocumentType

In RIM 2.07, DocumentType is found in the ActCode hierarchy where it is an abstract term.

Lvl          Type, Domain name and/or Mnemonic code        Concept ID          Mnemonic           Print Name    Definition/Description

1             A: ExternallyDefinedActCodes      V16493                              

*2               A: DocumentType         V10870                The kind of document. Possible values: discharge summary, progress note, Oncology note, etc.*

Austin’s Note: This was effectively a concept domain, except that at the time, in RIM 2.07, concept domains did not exist. The “A” in “*A: DocumentType”* indicates it’s an Abstract term.
h2. http://terminology.hl7.org/ValueSet/v3-EncounterDischargeDisposition

From the RIM v2.07 definition of EncounterDischargeDispostion vocabulary domain:

EncounterDischargeDisposition    

A code indicating patient status as of the ending service date of the period covered on this bill, as reported in FL6, Statement Covers Period. Values such as: Discharged to home or self care; Discharged/transferred to SNF, Discharged/transferred to an intermediate care facility (ICF); Expired; Hospice-medical facility. NUBC Form Locator 22

Austin's Note: RIM 2.07 did not have any values defined for EncounterDischargeDisposition. It was effectively a concept domain.
h2. http://terminology.hl7.org/ValueSet/v3-DrugEntity

Austin’s Comment: DrugEntity is an abstract term in the V3 entityCode codesystem drawn from RIM 2.07. It has three additional abstract terms as specializations. This is effectively a concept domain.

2               A: DrugEntity    V16530                A substance whose therapeutic effect is produced by chemical action within the body.

3                 A: ClinicalDrug              V16205                Any substance or mixture of substances manufactured, sold or represented for use in: (a) the diagnosis, treatment, mitigation or prevention of a disease, disorder, abnormal physical state, or its symptoms, in human beings or animals; (b) restoring, correcting or modifying organic functions in human beings or animals.

4                   A: ManufacturedDrug              V16206                Identifies a drug or the use of a drug as produced by a specific manufacturer

5                     A: PackagedDrugProductEntity           V19626                A drug product identified at the level of the package in which it is commonly distributed.
h2. http://terminology.hl7.org/ValueSet/v3-ManufacturerModelName

From the RIM v2.07 definition of ManufacturerModelName vocabulary domain:

ManufacturerModelName    

Provides coded names for attribute Device.manufacturerModelName, which has data type SC.

Austin's Note: RIM 2.07 did not have any values defined for ManufacturerModelName. It was effectively a concept domain.
column41:
2022-03-10 08:40;LisaRNelson;For this one: http://terminology.hl7.org/ValueSet/v3-ActClassOrganizer

Note name change will be http://terminology.hl7.org/ValueSet/v3-ActClassOrganizerRIM2-07

ORGANIZER, CATEGORY, DOCBODY, DOCSECT, TOPIC, FOLDER - Updated list as of 3/10...drop FOLDER and add ORGANIZER and its children.

Name changes for the others:
* http://terminology.hl7.org/ValueSet/v3-DocumentTypeExample

2020-09-25 11:45;rhausam;I'm not sure what is happening with this?  I want to apply the resolution for FHIR-19960 and also address FHIR-14302 (which is marked as waiting for input from Grahame). 

To do that properly, I think, will require:

(1) adding the additional codes for 'preferredForLanguage' and 'consumer' (or should we use 'preferred-for-language' and 'consumer-friendly'?) to the current [designation-usage|http://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/CodeSystem-designation-usage.html] code system in UTG

(2) updating the UTG [designation-usage|http://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/ValueSet-designation-usage.html] value set to include the 2 SNOMED CT codes
|*Code*|*Display*|
|[900000000000003001  !http://build.fhir.org/external.png!|http://browser.ihtsdotools.org/?perspective=full&conceptId1=900000000000003001]|Fully specified name|
|[900000000000013009  !http://build.fhir.org/external.png!|http://browser.ihtsdotools.org/?perspective=full&conceptId1=900000000000013009]|Synonym (core metadata concept)|

that are the contents currently of the [designation-use|http://build.fhir.org/valueset-designation-use.html] value set in the core FHIR spec

(3) update the bindings in the FHIR core spec in [CodeSystem.concept.designation.use|http://build.fhir.org/codesystem-definitions.html#CodeSystem.concept.designation.use] and [ValueSet.compose.include.concept.designation.use|http://build.fhir.org/valueset-definitions.html#ValueSet.compose.include.concept.designation.use] to refer to the UTG [designation-usage|http://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/ValueSet-designation-usage.html] value set (instead of the FHIR core [designation-use|http://build.fhir.org/valueset-designation-use.html] value set) (note that both resources are normative)
column38: 2020-09-25 08:41;rhausam;We should also look at and consider the proposal and questions in the SNOMED on FHIR project work on the [designation extension|https://confluence.ihtsdotools.org/display/FHIR/Designation+extension].  It seems unclear if or how this extension could be used with other code systems, but it appears likely much more useful for SNOMED CT than the extended value set approach.  Are both approaches needed?
column39:
2020-09-28 01:59;Rob_McClure;Restating my comments from [Zulip|[CodeSystem vs Valueset Disignation use[age|https://chat.fhir.org/#narrow/stream/179202-terminology/topic/CodeSystem.20vs.20Valueset.20Disignation.20use.5Bage.5D]]:

Seems we've twisted something simple into quite a knot. We discussed this at connectathon I believe. While I can not find any notes for the breakout on Designations, I seem to remember that there were a number of folks that shared @Grahame Grieve concern that [DesignationUse|http://build.fhir.org/valueset-designation-use.html] was specific to SNOMED CT code system use _exclusively_ and that we need more designation "types" in what we should be using everywhere: [DesignationUsage|http://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/ValueSet-designation-usage.html]. There does seem to be two UTG JIRA issues: 102 and 107 but lets follow @Rob Hausam advice and comment on 107. 

So I think we need to determine if we can remove the [DesignationUse|http://build.fhir.org/valueset-designation-use.html] value set, and if not, then make it only apply to SCT. I think we need to add additional concepts to Code System [DesignationUsage|[http://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/CodeSystem-designation-usage.html]] but at least display, synonym, and any others requested.
column40:
2020-09-28 04:38;GrahameGrieve;I think we should:

* keep the value set
* document that the snomed codes are appropriate only for snomed ct concepts
* add our own additional codes in our code system
* add "preferred for language" and "consumer" to the UTG code system
* improve the definition of display in the existing code (What is it not?)
column41:
2020-11-02 08:06;rhausam;So, for "keep the value set", there are 2 options that I see:
 * Keep the [designation-use|http://build.fhir.org/valueset-designation-use.html] value set definition as it is:
 ** In this case the 2 SNOMED CT codes for "Synonym" and "Fully specified name" will remain as the only content in the value set.
 ** The only change to the FHIR specification is to clarify that the SNOMED CT codes are only expected to be used *with* SNOMED CT, and not with other code systems (although presumably it would not be *prohibited* to use them with other code systems).
 ** Even though it's only a change in the text, I think that change would be "*Compatible, substantive*" because, with the extensible binding, where previously many (if not most or all of us) have interpreted the SNOMED CT code as the only option available for expressing the meaning of "synonym", now it will be possible to use any code (including local or non-SNOMED codes) to represent the meaning of "synonym", at least if the code system that is being used is *not* SNOMED CT. 
 ** We would add the `preferred for language` and `consumer` codes to "our code system" (i.e. [designation-usage|http://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/CodeSystem-designation-usage.html] in UTG) so they would be available for use in [CodeSystem.concept.designation.use|http://build.fhir.org/codesystem-definitions.html#CodeSystem.concept.designation.use] and 
[ValueSet.compose.include.concept.designation.use|http://build.fhir.org/valueset-definitions.html#ValueSet.compose.include.concept.designation.use].  
*But*, this would mean that beyond "Synonym" and "Fully specified name" for use with SNOMED CT, we would be providing *no guidance* for what other codes might be used in the 'designation.use' elements - *any* code (standard or local or otherwise) could be used to specify the designation use and the instance would be conformant.

 *  Update the [designation-use|http://build.fhir.org/valueset-designation-use.html] value set definition:
 ** In this case the value set definition would be updated to also include the codes in [designation-usage|http://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/CodeSystem-designation-usage.html].  So this would include the codes that are in that code system now (i.e. only `display`) and any others that we add in the future (e.g., `preferred for language`, `consumer`, etc.).
 ** With the extensible binding, I believe this would be a "*Non-compatible*" change.  For example, someone may have been using a designation use code from their own code system to indicate a "consumer friendly" term, which was a conformant use.  But now they would find that, with the extensible binding, the code that they had previously been using is, in fact, no longer conformant (if someone bothered to check it).
 ** A couple of side effects (which may not be at all significant) of this are that there would be no use (as far as I'm aware) for the UTG [designation-usage|http://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/ValueSet-designation-usage.html] value set.  Plus the [designation-use|http://build.fhir.org/valueset-designation-use.html] value set that is defined in the FHIR core spec, which is the one that we are using, is based in part on codes that are being defined in UTG (not in the FHIR spec itself or an external code system).
column42:
2020-09-29 04:21;mjlawley;Documenting that the SNOMED codes are only for SNOMED seems pretty revisionist.  Also, with respect to at least 900000000000013009 (Synonym), somewhat hairsplitting and change for change's sake.

What is the difference between "preferred for language" and "display"?

What  does "consumer" mean?

Whatever changes are made to the set, it needs to be clear which values (e.g., "display" in conjunction with language) have an impact on terminology server behaviour, and which are merely for "pass-through".
column43: 2020-09-29 04:39;mjlawley;SNOMED "Language" reference sets ([https://confluence.ihtsdotools.org/x/L4e2AQ)] are about specifying a notion of Acceptability which can vary depending on context (the specific reference set implicitly indicates the context).
column44:
2020-11-02 08:35;rhausam;The designation-use code system and value set updates issue was brought up again on the Vocab co-chairs call today.  I think we still need to answer the questions raised above (beginning with my comment on 2020-09-25 12:45) to determine explicitly and exactly what the needed changes are that will be applied so we can move this forward to completion. [~tedhl7geek] [~GrahameGrieve] [~mjlawley] [~Rob_McClure] [~cmacumber] [~carmela_couderc] [~reuben.daniels] 

We can move the discussion back to [Zulip|https://chat.fhir.org/#narrow/stream/179202-terminology/topic/CodeSystem.20vs.20Valueset.20Disignation.20use.5Bage.5D] or one of the FHIR core trackers (FHIR-14302 is still open) if we think that would be useful - or we can continue it here.
column45:
2020-11-04 12:51;daniel.karlsson@socialstyrelsen.se;There is work done by the SNOMED on FHIR Terminology Services work group to develop an extension to represent three aspects of the designation used by SNOMED but also similarly in other terminologies. The three designation (description) aspects that SNOMED distinguishes are:
 * The designation type (FSN, synonym, or textual definition)
 * The designation use context (language dialects, domain specific use contexts such as consumer-friendly, nursing, medical specialty specific terms, etc.)
 * The role of the designation in that context, for SNOMED whether the designation is preferred or acceptable in that use context (i.e. acceptability). "preferredForLanguage" seems to fall in this category.

Other code systems make use of at least some of these aspects; LOINC has fully specified, short, long common, and consumer names, ICD-10 has different kinds of rubric etc. 

As you all know there is only one designation.use element to cover these three aspects, and a SNOMED CT subset for designation type, debatably the least useful use aspect, was chosen. The work done by the SNOMED on FHIR group (documented [here|https://confluence.ihtsdotools.org/display/FHIR/Mechanisms+for+working+with+Languages]) has led to a proposal for an extension [here|https://github.com/IHTSDO/snomed-ig/blob/duc/fsh/fsh-source/DesignationUseContextExtension.fsh] for discussion.

However, if there is an opportunity to change the current binding to allow designation.use to represent the designation use context instead of designation type and hence replace the value set with a set of designation use contexts for commonly used code systems, that would be the preferred option.
column46: 2020-11-05 02:52;Rob_McClure;Goodness we can make things complicated. I think we need to consider making the cardinality of xx.concept.designation.use 0..* and then allow something to identified with "types, use context, and role." Yes that means you'd need special concatenated terms where something might apply to multiple things but I challenge anyone to give me multiple real examples where this is true. This would obviously be a r5 change and we need to follow can-we-break-it rules.
column47:
2020-11-10 05:58;daniel.karlsson@socialstyrelsen.se;"as simple as possible, but no simpler"

Challenge accepted: the multiple real examples are in the text above: SYN and FSN (already in the value set), "preferredForLanguage" and "consumer-friendly" could well appear at the same time. And SNOMED CT does describe these aspects all of the time for all descriptions/designations.
column48: 2020-11-17 01:44;mjlawley;As noted above, the semantics of "preferredForLanguage" are covered with designation.use value of "display" – why do we need to add a new code carries the same semantics?
column49: 2020-11-17 03:59;tedhl7geek;Michael, I do not see or find a designation_use value of "display" and as far as I know it is not used.    Can you point me to where it might have been defined?
column50: 2020-11-24 02:49;tedhl7geek;the final state of the content of the value set needs to be the two existing SNOMED CT codes, plus the addition of the two code values [http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/hl7TermMaintInfra#preferredForLanguage] and [http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/hl7TermMaintInfra#consumer|http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/hl7TermMaintInfra#preferredForLanguage]
column51:
2020-11-26 10:04;daniel.karlsson@socialstyrelsen.se;Sorry,

as the cardinality is 0..1 and binding is extensible, having all codes in the same valueset would prohibit any possibility of having a consumer preferred synonym. Further, the extension we've been working on which lets the code system provide additional information about context of use, description type, and acceptability would also break. Understanding the urgency of a solution, we're (as in the community developing the extension) happy to discuss solutions to all our needs, but please do not rush a solution with such consequences.
column52:
2020-11-26 09:38;mjlawley;The context comes from this ticket  FHIR-14302 

It is used in the spec itself right here [https://hl7.org/fhir/R4/languages.html##term]

column56:
2020-12-01 02:05;mjlawley;Hi [~tedhl7geek],

During discussion on today's SNOMED on FHIR call we dug into the {{display}} vs {{preferredForLanguage}} topic.

It seems that sometime after the 1st ballot for R4 ([http://hl7.org/fhir/2018May/languages.html##term]) the CodeSystem defining display was erroneously moved from [http://hl7.org/fhir/CodeSystem/designation-usage] to [http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/designation-usage] .

I say erroneously because the semantics of {{display}} are intrinsic to the behaviour of FHIR Terminology Services (ie selection of preferred term for a given language, e.g., in the presence of the display-language parameter to ValueSet/$expand) and thus should live in the core FHIR Spec.  However, I suspect it's not a particularly useful thing to re-re-name this CodeSystem just for the sake of purity so I would suggest we're stuck with the current URI even though it should be "owned" by the FHIR spec itself.

Now, unless the intent is for {{preferredForLanguage}} to be a purely client-side indicator, it would seem to duplicate (and post-date) the semantics of {{display}} and thus it should be dropped in preference to {{display}}.

I would also argue that making it a client-side indicator is against the spirit of FHIR Terminology Services which is to offload work to the server and make the client's life simpler.
column57:
2020-12-03 02:50;GrahameGrieve;it wasn't moved erroneously - it was moved correctly. But moving it shouldn't be taken to mean that servers aren't expected to care about it - of course they must. that's why the value set is extensible - it's reasonable for servers to know the codes in the value set itself. 

{{preferredForLanguage}} doesn't a duplication of 'display'. it's full name might be '{{preferredDisplayForLanguage}} ' - it is a display, yes, but it's additionally preferred for the language (though the meaning of that is most definitely slippery)
column58:
2020-12-03 02:51;carmela_couderc;Discussed on the 12/3/2020 FHIR Tracker call.

Discussion: preferredForLanguage and display do not have the same meaning; both should be in the value set. 

The SNOMED on FHIR work on designation use extension should continue (to capture qualifications on designation use - acceptability), and be considered for a standard extension to make it available for general use. Defining as a standard extension would be beneficial for clients. 

Peter Jordan suggests that a decision tree be created to help determine whether an extension is required. 

This ticket can move ahead independent of the SNOMED on FHIR decision.
column60: 2020-12-15 02:35;mjlawley;For the record, can we have a clear explanation of how preferredForLanguage and display are different (as used in my above example https://jira.hl7.org/browse/UP-107?focusedCommentId=180345&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-180345)
column61:
2021-02-09 02:13;mjlawley;bump :) still waiting for clarification on the semantic differences between preferredForLanguage and display.

[~tedhl7geek]?

Progress on an approach for handling of "language reference sets" in the SNOMED on FHIR group is reaching a point where we need to resolve this issue.
column62: 2021-02-19 11:39;mjlawley;Also noting here that [http://build.fhir.org/codesystem-definitions.html#CodeSystem.concept.designation] has text in the Comment that indicates the existence of an additional code, "primary code", albeit without a specified CodeSystem.
column63:
2021-02-26 04:19;daniel.karlsson@socialstyrelsen.se;Dear All,

in trying to guide our Swedish FHIR users we would like some more clarity on the difference between "display" and "preferredForLanguage". Further, as the representation of SNOMED CT output (e.g. expansion) likely will require an extension, guidance on the priority between existing codes (SYN+FSN), "consumer", "display", and "preferredForLanguage" is needed when multiple codes can be used. E.g. how should designation.use be coded for a preferred, consumer, synonym used as display? Are multiple designations required?

Thanks,
Daniel
column64: 2022-04-19 02:56;pgwilliams;The SNOMED on FHIR group discussed this ticket today and expressed a mild preference for "preferredForLanguage", and that if this was added to [http://build.fhir.org/valueset-designation-use.html] , then "display" would not be required as an additional value.

2021-12-22 01:09;tedhl7geek;[~sheridancook] you need to Draft A Proposal, which consists pf defining the changes needed in the xml resources.  As this is an HL7 V2 table, you will need probably the INM workgroup to sponsor the change proposal; if the additions are purely for Canada, I am not sure there is a process for sponsorship of a terminology change in the THO set by an Affiliate - no defined process so you would have to go through TSMG (do you agree [~jsnell] and [~reuben.daniels]?)     see the pages linked on the page about Vocabulary Maintenance at HL7 [https://confluence.hl7.org/display/VMAH/Vocabulary+Maintenance+at+HL7]

2022-01-31 10:16;j_harper;I have made the changes to the codesystem cs-v2-0203 (_HL7v2 Table 0203 Identifier Type_) to add an identifier for JPID.  

Please review the changes.
column41: 2022-02-02 12:31;lloyd;The definition for the new code is poor.  What does it mean?  How is it different from a JHN?  Do JPIDs span patient and practitioner roles?
column42: 2022-02-02 01:14;jduteau;Can you provide examples of a Canadian JPID?  The description “Federal Identifier that can be used along with Jurisdictional Health Number” isn’t clear enough for me.  Is this a Passport number?  A Driver’s License number? A treaty number?  All of those already have codes.  As well, I’m confused by the use of the term “Federal” since that applies a specific jurisdiction that might be Canadian-specific.
column43:
2022-02-02 02:53;sheridancook;[~lloyd] [~jduteau] This request follows the [analysis work|https://infocentral.infoway-inforoute.ca/en/forum/266-fhir-implementations/2171-call-to-review-namingsystem-profile] that was completed previously to type the identifiers used in the Canadian NamingSystem Registry. A need arose to distinguish identifiers in use in Canadian systems from the JHN that is defined as a provincial health card number. Use of this type is intended to span identifiers that are issued under federal jurisdictions as well as provincial jurisdictions to a person it is not intended to be isolated to identifiers issued for healthcare delivery purposes but it's important to note that this type of identifier may be used within those workflows. 

The following are examples that fell under the proposed type of JPID from the efforts of the Canadian URI Registry: [Canada, Social Insurance Number;|https://simplifier.net/canadianuriregistry/ca-social-insurance-number] [Interim Federal Health Program Identifier, |https://simplifier.net/canadianuriregistry/ca-interim-federal-health-id] [Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada number|https://simplifier.net/canadianuriregistry/ca-indigenous-northern-affairs-number]

In the last year - this type has been requested and used by implementers looking to type identifiers that are assigned by provincial jurisdictional assets (e.g., myHealthNB) that are distinct from the health card number that person might have within the jurisdiction, but may be similarly needed to retrieve data for the person using that identifier. 

Rather than have profilers and implementers using this type either provide no code system or a local system to get around errors from trying to claim this type - we're requesting it's inclusion in the v2-0203 code system.
column44: 2022-02-02 02:49;jduteau;But there are already Identifier type codes for those.  We already have PN - Person Number, TN - Treaty Number, etc.  I'm still confused over how this differs from those.
column45:
2022-02-02 03:26;sheridancook;Many of the types in the code system could fall under the definition of Person Number ("A number that is unique to a living subject within an Assigning Authority.") - The presence of over 70+ codes in the existing code systems shows precedence that granularity matters for identifier type.  

For our implementers in Canada - this type has been used to further differentiate identifiers in the registry for 3+ years, and more recently is starting to be used by jurisdictions working with legacy systems that want to maintain that differentiation (between business identifiers, health card #s, and identifiers that have been issued by federal and provincial programs) when they begin to model their data in FHIR. The desire to obtain this separate type is also felt by FHIR profilers wanting to apply expectations for how/when certain identifier types are used - slices differentiating between JHN, JPID, etc. are in use by the Canadian base specification, provincial base specifications, and other regional and use case driven specs in Canada.
column46:
2022-02-02 03:47;jduteau;I still don't understand the need for this code.  You say that you want more granularity than existing codes but this is not a very granular code given the types of identifiers that would fall under this.

For future implementers who wanted to specify the type of identifier for an Indigenous and Northern Affairs Canada number, how would they possibly know that JPID vs TN vs PN?

It just seems to me that existing codes would satisfy the requirement, especially since Identifier types are intended to be general categories and the identifier system tells you exactly what the identifier is for.
column47: 2022-02-02 04:48;lloyd;There's already an identifier type that covers "Social Beneficiary Numbers" - of which U.S. SSN and Canadian SIN are examples.  We don't want types that overlap if we can possibly avoid it.  So if we're adding something new, it would need to explicitly exclude SBNs.  In any case, if this is going to be allowed for use with FHIR, the definition needs to make clear what's in, what's out and ensure it doesn't overlap with the existing identifier types.
column48: 2022-02-15 11:57;j_harper;We have discussed this issue in the HL7 Canada Community and will be withdrawing this request.

column41: 2020-09-23 02:10;Rob_McClure;[~jfrancis] Agree with the comments noted above. I am also concerned about the chosen final Canonical URLs. You have chosen to use the url that currently identifies the CCI code system to now (and forever) identify ICD-10-CA. I understand that url does indeed have the ICD-10-CA phrase in it but I would assume that the confusion by reusing an identifier actually makes things worse. Why not use a completely new url as you are doing for the new CCI code system identifier?
column42:
2020-09-24 06:29;jfrancis;Thank you [~jsnell] and [~cmacumber] for the detailed explanation on the changes required. Much appreciated. I have made the proposed changes :)

Just want to confirm with [~tedhl7geek] that changing the "name" element field in the CodeSystem stub addresses the lower case/upper case naming issues. i.e, Cci to CCI? Is there any other place I need to make the changes?
column43:
2020-09-24 06:26;jfrancis;[~Rob_McClure] thank you for the comment and feedback. The issue of the CCI CodeSystem pointing to ICD-10-CA is a mistake prior to my submission of proposal(pre implementation). 

Once this proposal is implemented CCI uri : [http://cihi.ca/fhir/CodeSystem/cihi-cci] instead of [http://hl7.org/fhir/sid/icd-10-ca.|http://hl7.org/fhir/sid/icd-10-ca]

I wasn't sure how this error with the meta data was made in the first place. Does this help?
column44: 2020-09-24 09:33;jfrancis;[~tedhl7geek] changes made and committed. I had some difficulty for  SourceTree picking up a change and removing  blank space helped me.  I replaced end date with an empty string. Hopefully that doesn't break the build.
column45: 2020-09-24 10:46;Rob_McClure;That explains the provenance of the current state, but does not address my concern with respect to the fact that the mistake is in current production use. I'm suggesting you *do not reuse and change the meaning of* the existing canonical url. And honestly I'm not sure _why_ you would want to use that one anyway.
column46: 2020-09-25 01:06;tedhl7geek;It is my understanding that we need to approach changing any canonical URLs that are rooted in hl7.org/fhir with extreme caution (unlike those generated by the v3 coremif import into UTG rooted in terminology.hl7.org) as we don't know how many production systems they may be currently used in.   I do not know how best to figure this out; perhaps [~lloyd] can offer some insight here.
column47: 2020-09-25 01:55;lloyd;Agree.  As a rule, cannonical URLs should *never* change once they're established.  We can add a link to the current authoritative source in the NamingSystem, but changing canonical URLs breaks interoperability
column48:
2020-09-28 08:58;jfrancis;[~tedhl7geek] [~lloyd]n [~Rob_McClure]

What I don't understand is that this URL was perhaps made up at a connectathon and systems ought to be using the OID instead until the authoritative source in question publishes a valid URI. This URI points to a whole different CodeSystem than what was actually intended.  

So what I am hearing is do not change the URI but perhaps in the description of the NamingSystem resource mention the correct URI as the authoritative source?

cc: [~amaclean]
column49: 2020-09-28 09:18;lloyd;Someone submitted a formal request to register the URL.  Now that it's registered, it is significantly problematic to change it - unless you're confident that no existing implementations are using it (which is unlikely given that the URL got registered a while ago).  If there's a registered URL, then you can't use an OID to identify the code system in FHIR - and our general objective is to use URLs in place of OIDs wherever possible because OIDs are much harder to work with for implementers and the cost of managing the conversion (using NamingSystem) is less than the long-term cost of continuing to use OIDs.  We can absolutely update the NamingSystem to point to the current authoritative URL for source-of-truth.  (Those URLs change semi-often.)
column50: 2020-09-28 12:41;Rob_McClure;[~lloyd] honestly, this is starting to border on the absurd. The url that I asked [~jfrancis] about was for CCI and ends in icd-10-ca. So we are clear, are you saying that the canonical url for CCI *MUST* be the url that ends in icd-10-ca because it was that before and then we'll have a different one that also ends in icd-10-ca for the actual icd-10-ca? Let's not talk in theoretical absolutes. Lloyd, please indicate what you are advocating for explicitly.
column51:
2020-09-28 02:09;lloyd;Ok, so I think the first question here is: where did these URLs come from and where have they previously been published?

"http://hl7.org/fhir/sid/icd-10-ca" *looks* like something that was registered with FHIR, but I can't see any reference to it in the FHIR core spec.  It's also not something the FHIR server currently recognizes, which suggests it was never registered.  On the other hand, I see no indication that "http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/icd10-CA" was ever previously published in the FHIR spec before UTG got stood up.  In order to know which URL should survive, we need to understand what's been published where & when and, most importantly, what's most likely in use in real systems.  Whatever we choose as 'official' should be the one most likely to be in use (and should act expediently to remove all references saying anything else, except as something deprecated.

In terms of [http://hl7.org/fhir/sid/icd-10-ca] showing up as a URL for CCI, we need to understand where that came from too.  If it was just an error in standing up UTG, then fixing it is a simple technical correction.  It seems unlikely that any implementer would ever have used this as a URL for CCI, so the risk to fixing it is small.
column52: 2020-09-28 03:31;tedhl7geek;I can unequivocally state that the URL "http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/icd10-CA" was algorithmically created by the coremif import into UTG, and was not published anywhere prior to the 1.0.0 release in April 2020.   The only reason this should IMHO stay in the NamingSystem track for it as an old and non-preferred identifier is we simply do not know if anyone picked it up from the HL7 Terminology release in the past five months and used it - but the likelihood is low.
column53:
2020-09-29 06:48;jfrancis;After many discussions with [~tedhl7geek], I understood the format "http://terminology/something" to be a placeholder until a valid URI existed and the metadata was changed explicitly to reflect the change. 

The current CCI description which is also not entirely accurate was taken from the description in the HL7 OID registry from 2009. If the URL was stood up in error, can we proceed with the current proposal to implement the change in the URI and description?
column54:
2020-09-30 11:46;jfrancis;[~tedhl7geek]  [~Rob_McClure] [~lloyd] We have raised the issue of the URL in production on the various Canadian forums and have received no comments thus far.  Therefore it is our intention to make the changes as per the proposal and not perpetuate the mistake how/when ever it may have occurred. 

Would you please kindly consider voting in favour of this change.

 

cc [~amaclean] [~Rongparker] [~j_harper] [~jsnell] [~cmacumber]
column55:
2020-09-30 11:55;jsnell;[~jfrancis], one more fix request. On the effective date period you added for the Naming Systems, I think the end date should be removed. This will indicate that the identifier was established for use on 9/24 and is considered effective with no end date in sight. 

<period>

<start value="2020-09-24" />

{color:#de350b}<end value="2020-09-24" /> {color}

</period>

column61: 2020-10-01 09:16;Rob_McClure;Just one straw in the bale [~jfrancis], no worries because that is what I needed to know. You have my vote.
column63: 2020-10-01 09:26;lloyd;Using HL7-managed SIDs is an appropriate mechanism for identifying external objects, especially if there's any concern about the ability of the organization to maintain stable resolution of the URL (stable =many decades of zero change).  HL7 SIDs can be guaranteed to resolve - and we can always have them point to changing locations.
column64:
2020-10-01 09:48;jfrancis;[~lloyd] can you please explain this concept with an existing concrete example? I am not able to follow. 

cc: [~amaclean]
column65: 2020-10-01 09:53;jfrancis;[~Josh] [~tedhl7geek], now that we have received consensus, can you please advise regarding the commit issues.
column66: 2020-10-01 09:58;lloyd;HL7 has committed to the SID links resolving - presumably to the associated NamingSystem resource.  NamingSystem.description can include a hyperlink that refers to the 'current' web page for guidance on use, instructions for getting current content, etc. from the "source of truth".  If/when the location of the appropriate website(s) change, the NamingSystem can be updated.  None of that changes the URL used in instances - which remains the SID URI.

column35:
2021-02-23 08:40;jsnell;From discussion about this entry ([https://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem-HCPCS.html)] with Rob McClure on 2/23. 
 * This identifier is for the entirety of HCPCS (Level I - CPT, Level II - HCPCS, Level III - Modifiers) and should never be used in current electronic interchange. Therefore, this code system with this identifier will be retired in THO. The definition of this entry will be updated to include this information about its use. The 'garbage' fragment content will be removed from this entry as well. 
 ** No naming system entry will be created for this retired code system 
 * New external code system and naming system entries will be added to THO for HCPCS Level II. 
 * The HCPCS value set ([http://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/ValueSet-v3-HealthCareCommonProcedureCodingSystem.html)] will point to the new HCPCS Level II code system and not the retired entry. The definition will also clarify that it includes Level II codes.

column5: Fix NUCC Provider Taxonomy to be correct per HTA
column35:
2020-06-26 12:39;jsnell;The following fields were updated for the artifacts listed in 'change objects' above. 
 # URL - updated to [http://www.nucc.org/taxonomy]
 # Date - updated to 6/26/2020
 # Version - updated to 3.0.0 from 2.0.0, we actually haven't discussed updating externals and Naming Systems yet but it would surprise me if updating identifiers is NOT a major change. 
 # Publisher - I fixed an existing typo (Uniforam to Uniform)

[~Rob_McClure], please review the changes thoroughly (once Ted pushes the ticket to Consensus Review) as I'm not entirely sure what else needs to be updated from the HTA page for NUCC. More specifically:
 # Should we update the Definition for NUCC based on HTA's Scope/domain statement for the code system? 
 # There is a Value Set for NUCC Provider Taxonomy ([https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/ValueSet-v3-NUCCProviderCodes.html)|https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/ValueSet-v3-NUCCProviderCodes.html] and I'm assuming this needs updating as well. I assume the system will need to point to the updated URI. I think there are many more Value Sets that point to the Provider Taxonomy as well. Will those all need to be updated? If so, will other fields? Versions? 

I will be out of the office all next week, but wanted to get this feedback to you today so if this raises any policy issues you have time to discuss them.

column39: 2020-06-29 01:32;Rob_McClure;As Jessica noted, the value set [https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/ValueSet-v3-NUCCProviderCodes.html)|https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/ValueSet-v3-NUCCProviderCodes.html] is defined as all the codes in the Health Care Provider Taxonomy code system. The expansion in UTG has made up code - all begin with "base-" - and those codes must be removed. Unclear if that is part of this change, I suspect not.

column36: 2020-06-21 02:37;RikiM;Agree with using HL70532
column37:
2020-06-22 06:27;craig.newman;It says "Compose: All from code system 2.16.840.1.113883.18.347"  but:

1) that OID seems to be applicable to both table 0136 and 0532 in v2.9 Ch02C. Is that right? Can it apply to both tables?

2) this statement reads like all codes in the table (0532) are included in the value set but that's not true. Or does this mean that all the codes in the value set are from that OID?
column38:
2020-06-22 10:22;tedhl7geek;Craig, 1) the OID identifies the CODE SYSTEM.  Tables are not code systems; their enumerated content is inforemated by value sets built on underlying code system content.   The code system of V2 expanded yes/no codes is identified by that OID; the two tables have different value sets as they have different subsets of the codes in them.  The tables are each asociated with an table OID, and if they have listed codes, a value set OID and a code system OID.   The compose for the new value set indicates only the four codes from the code system are included in the expansion.    On the rendered page it shows: Logical Definition (CLD)
 * Include these codes as defined in [{{http://terminology.hl7.org/CodeSystem/v2-0532}}|https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/branches/UP-71-new-value-set-request-yesnounknownnotasked/CodeSystem-v2-0532.html] version {{2.1.0}}
|*Code*|*Display*|
|[Y|https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/branches/UP-71-new-value-set-request-yesnounknownnotasked/CodeSystem-v2-0532.html#v2-0532-Y]|Yes|Yes|
|[N|https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/branches/UP-71-new-value-set-request-yesnounknownnotasked/CodeSystem-v2-0532.html#v2-0532-N]|No|No|
|[ASKU|https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/branches/UP-71-new-value-set-request-yesnounknownnotasked/CodeSystem-v2-0532.html#v2-0532-ASKU]|Unknown|asked but unknown|
|[NASK|https://build.fhir.org/ig/HL7/UTG/branches/UP-71-new-value-set-request-yesnounknownnotasked/CodeSystem-v2-0532.html#v2-0532-NASK]|Not Asked|not asked|
column39: 2020-06-22 12:46;Josh;admin function to add linked upsm-10
column40: 2020-06-22 12:48;Josh;admin function to add linked upsm-10
column42:
2020-08-12 03:12;carmela_couderc;Thanks for your question [~rhausam].

Rather than create the value set drawn from two code systems, I decided to use one that contains all the necessary concepts. Another issue is that the definition of not-asked in the FHIR DataAbsentReason code system is "the workflow didn't lead to this value being known". That seemed odd and doesn't fit the use case/reason the DRLS project created this value set.

In the Review of Systems, as a clinician is moving through the _systems_ on a form/questionnaire_,_ the workflow might absolutely lead to the potential for the question to be asked, but the clinician decided not to ask it - possibly because the system in question (e.g. gastrointestinal) is not critical to evaluate for the encounter (e.g. evaluation for non-emergency ambulance transport).  

That is why I selected the V2 code system.
column43: 2020-10-15 02:29;carmela_couderc;[~ahenket]  or [~sylvia_thun] or [~Rongparker] would one or both of you please vote on this proposal? Thanks.
column44:
2020-10-29 10:23;ahenket;Yes/No/ASKU/NASK is a pretty common pattern. However, plain UNK (unknown) is even more common. UNK is a tad less specific than ASKU/NASK would be. You basically would not know if it had been asked or not in that case.

Both the [NullFlavor extension|http://build.fhir.org/extension-iso21090-nullflavor.html] and the [data-absent-reason extension|http://build.fhir.org/extension-data-absent-reason.html] both cover the "unknown" part of the value set. Why reinvent that part in a different code system? Could the value set not combine codes from 2 code systems? Asking a person something is (albeit minimal) some form of workflow so I do not see its definition as a valid point towards dismissing applicability.

Lastly: Yes and No and unknown all exist in SNOMED CT as
 * [373066001|http://terminologie.nictiz.nl/art-decor/snomed-ct?conceptId=373066001] | Yes (qualifier value) |
 * [373067005|http://terminologie.nictiz.nl/art-decor/snomed-ct?conceptId=373067005] | No (qualifier value) |
 * [261665006|http://terminologie.nictiz.nl/art-decor/snomed-ct?conceptId=261665006] | Unknown (qualifier value) |
 * [1631000175102|http://terminologie.nictiz.nl/art-decor/snomed-ct?conceptId=1631000175102] | Patient not asked (contextual qualifier) (qualifier value) |

Do we really need to prolong V2 in FHIR?
column45: 2020-10-29 11:25;RikiM;The reason to have asked but unknown vs just unknown has something to do with measure counting - important to differntiate between was this question asked (becasue it's part of a measure or not aasked) = but both result in the value being unknown. not sure if this is the case for this, but that's what I have seen in other places (instead of asked but unknown could be "declined to state").

column5: All value sets using NUCC code system should be removed
column35: 2020-06-09 05:40;tedhl7geek;So you need to create a branch with the actual change, not just describe it in prose.   All of the affected objects need to be explicitly listed; no one is going to look them up for you.   We also need a Vocabulary Policy for removal of value sets, which we do not have.     We also have had in HL7 for many years a policy that code systems are not just removed; they are first deprecated then retired.   Just like concepts in a code system.   If these are reference in v2 then it also involved the v2 tables in question as well.  All objects must be identified,, enumerated, and 'removed' - which may be deleted from the source of truth and the manifests, but that should be decided on the Vocabulary call this week. [~Rob_McClure] a pretty fair amount of technical work to do on this before being able to submit it.
column36: 2020-06-09 05:49;Rob_McClure;Ted, you are making this too hard. We need to allow people to write just as I have. Then we need to decide how to get the work done.

Who knew?   Josh Mandel found and verified the issue.  Your content btw looks perfect...can you create the Bitbucket branch name WITHOUT the slash - most simply just don't use the "bugfix/" prefix to it.   The issue has been documented as a bug in the IGPublisher, but who knows when it might get fixed.      If you do this and recreate the branch with a valid name, I can send it through to Consensus Review tonight (going to be flying cross country all day tomorrow).   Thanks.   PS.  Grahame noted that due to an issue in the process of importing the FHIR value sets and code systems to UTG, inadvertently the narratives got imported as well.   Oops.   I will work with him to see if we can apply a script fix to the whole shebang so you don't have any worries about it.
